title: Install the game on my Windows PC
user_role: A new player who has just acquired the game
description: As a new player who has just acquired the game, I want to run a simple, guided installer on my Windows PC so that I can get the game set up correctly and quickly, allowing me to start my first playthrough without technical frustration.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given I have downloaded the standalone installer package for 'Monopoly Tycoon' and have administrative rights on my Windows PC, when I execute the installer and follow the on-screen prompts, accepting all default settings (installation path, desktop shortcut), then the installer wizard guides me through a welcome screen, license agreement, location selection, and installation progress, concluding with a 'Finished' screen.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given I am on the license agreement screen of the installation wizard, when I do not check the 'I accept the agreement' box, then the 'Next' button remains disabled, preventing me from continuing the installation.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given I have started the installation wizard, when I click the 'Cancel' button at any step before the file installation begins and confirm my choice, then the wizard closes, and no game files are written to my system.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Inno Setup script is peer-reviewed and merged into the main branch, A distributable installer package (`.exe`) is successfully built, Manual E2E testing is completed on all target Windows versions, The installer is digitally signed

title: Choose a custom installation directory
user_role: A Windows PC user with specific preferences for software organization or disk space management.
description: As a Windows PC user installing the game, I want to be able to choose a custom installation directory so that I can manage my disk space and organize my installed applications according to my personal preferences.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given the user is running the game installer and has reached the 'Choose Install Location' screen, when the user clicks the 'Browse...' button, selects a valid directory on a different drive (e.g., 'D:\\Games'), and proceeds with the installation, then the installer successfully installs all game files into the 'D:\\Games\\MonopolyTycoon' directory and the installation completes without errors.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the user is on the 'Choose Install Location' screen, when the user views the screen or selects a different drive, then the UI accurately displays the total disk space required for the game and the available disk space on the currently selected drive, updating dynamically when the drive is changed.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given the user is on the 'Choose Install Location' screen, when the user selects a directory on a drive where the available space is less than the required space, then the installer displays a clear error message stating 'Insufficient disk space' and the 'Next' or 'Install' button is disabled until a valid location with enough space is selected.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Code (Inno Setup script) reviewed and approved by team, The installer has been successfully built with the new functionality, Manual end-to-end testing completed successfully on all target platforms

title: Provide an option to create a desktop shortcut during installation
user_role: Any user installing the Monopoly Tycoon game on their Windows PC.
description: As a new player installing the game, I want to see a checkbox option to create a desktop shortcut during the installation process, so that I can easily find and launch the game directly from my desktop after it's installed.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given the user is running the game installer on a supported Windows OS, when the user navigates to the 'Select Additional Tasks' screen in the installer and sees the 'Create a desktop shortcut' option is checked by default, and they proceed with the installation without changing this option, then a shortcut named 'Monopoly Tycoon' is created on the user's desktop upon successful installation.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given a desktop shortcut was created via the installer, when the user inspects the shortcut's properties, then the shortcut displays the official game icon and its target path correctly points to the game's primary executable in the chosen installation directory.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given the user is running the game installer, when the user unchecks the 'Create a desktop shortcut' option and completes the installation, then no shortcut for 'Monopoly Tycoon' is created on the user's desktop.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing on target OS versions., Inno Setup script changes are peer-reviewed and merged into the main development branch., Story deployed and verified in staging environment

title: Ensure UI and Game View Adapt to Different Monitor Aspect Ratios
user_role: Any Windows PC gamer, particularly those with widescreen (16:9), ultrawide (21:9), or legacy (16:10, 4:3) monitors.
description: As a PC gamer with a monitor of any common aspect ratio, I want the game's user interface and 3D view to automatically adapt to my screen's dimensions so that I can play the game without any visual distortion, overlapping elements, or loss of critical information, ensuring a high-quality and fully functional experience.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given the game is launched in fullscreen mode on a display with a 16:9 aspect ratio (e.g., 1920x1080), when the user navigates to the main gameplay screen, then the game board is fully visible and centered, all HUD elements are positioned correctly in their designated corners without overlapping, and no graphical elements are stretched or compressed.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the game is launched in fullscreen mode on a display with a 21:9 aspect ratio (e.g., 2560x1080), when the user views the main gameplay screen, then the game board maintains its correct proportions and is centered, with extra background visuals visible on the sides (pillarboxing of the 3D view is acceptable).
acceptance_criteria_3: Given the game is running in windowed mode, when the user clicks and drags the window border to change its size and aspect ratio, then the UI layout and game view dynamically update to fit the new dimensions upon releasing the mouse button.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing on 16:9, 16:10, and 21:9 aspect ratios., Code reviewed and approved by team, specifically checking for robust UI anchoring and scaling logic., Manual E2E testing confirms no visual regressions or functional breakages on supported resolutions.

title: Receive guidance on locating log files after an error
user_role: Any player of 'Monopoly Tycoon' experiencing an application-level unhandled exception.
description: As a player who has encountered an unexpected game crash, I want to be shown a clear error message that includes a unique error ID and instructions on where to find the log files, so that I understand a problem has been recorded and I can easily provide developers with the necessary information to diagnose and fix the bug.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given the game is running and an unhandled exception occurs in the application's code, when the global exception handler catches the exception, then a modal error dialog is displayed, blocking interaction with the game window.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the error dialog is displayed, when the user views the dialog content, then the dialog contains a non-technical message (e.g., 'An unexpected error has occurred'), a unique Error ID, and the full, absolute path to the user's log directory (e.g., '%APPDATA%/MonopolyTycoon/logs').
acceptance_criteria_3: Given an unhandled exception has been caught and an Error ID is displayed to the user, when the exception is processed by the logging system, then a log entry at the 'ERROR' level is written to the log file, containing the full exception details (message, stack trace) and the exact same Error ID shown in the dialog.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Code reviewed and approved by at least one other developer, The UI of the error dialog has been reviewed and approved for clarity and style consistency, Manual testing confirms the end-to-end flow from crash to log file verification

title: Uninstall the game cleanly from my computer
user_role: A Windows user who has previously installed Monopoly Tycoon and now wishes to remove it.
description: As a Windows PC user who no longer wishes to keep the game installed, I want a standard and thorough uninstallation process so that I can completely remove all application files and reclaim my disk space, ensuring my system remains clean.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given the game is successfully installed on a Windows machine, when the user navigates to 'Apps & features', selects 'Monopoly Tycoon', and clicks 'Uninstall', then the uninstallation wizard is launched, and the game's entry is removed from the 'Apps & features' list upon completion.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the user has initiated the uninstallation process and confirmed they wish to proceed, when the uninstaller completes successfully, then the main installation directory and all its contents are deleted, the desktop shortcut is removed (if created), and the Start Menu folder/shortcut is removed.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given the Monopoly Tycoon game application is currently running, when the user attempts to launch the uninstaller, then the uninstaller displays a clear error message stating the game must be closed before proceeding and will not continue until the application is terminated.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Code (Inno Setup script) reviewed and approved by team, Security requirements validated (UAC prompt, digital signature), Story deployed and verified in a staging/QA build

title: Choose to keep my personal data upon uninstallation
user_role: Any user of Monopoly Tycoon on Windows who has generated personal data (profiles, save games, statistics) and is now uninstalling the application.
description: As a Windows PC Gamer who needs to uninstall the game, I want to be given a clear choice to keep or delete my personal game data (like save files and player profile) during the uninstallation process so that I can reinstall the game later without losing all my progress and achievements.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given the game is installed and the user has created personal data located in the '%APPDATA%/MonopolyTycoon' directory, when the user runs the uninstaller and selects 'No' at the prompt asking to remove personal data, then the application files and shortcuts are completely removed, but the '%APPDATA%/MonopolyTycoon' directory and all its contents remain untouched.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the game is installed and the user has created personal data located in the '%APPDATA%/MonopolyTycoon' directory, when the user runs the uninstaller and selects 'Yes' at the prompt asking to remove personal data, then the application files and shortcuts are completely removed, AND the '%APPDATA%/MonopolyTycoon' directory and all its contents are also deleted.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given the game is installed but has never been run, so no '%APPDATA%/MonopolyTycoon' directory has been created, when the user runs the uninstaller, then the uninstallation process completes successfully without presenting a prompt to remove personal data.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Inno Setup script changes are peer-reviewed and merged, Manual E2E testing of all scenarios has been completed and passed on a target Windows OS, The installer package has been rebuilt with the updated uninstaller logic

title: Start a new game from the main menu
user_role: Any player (new or returning) who has launched the application with the intent to play.
description: As a player, I want to select a 'New Game' option from the main menu so that I can proceed to the game setup screen and configure a new match.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given the player is on the main menu screen, when the player clicks the 'New Game' button, then the application transitions to the Game Setup screen, and the main menu screen is no longer visible or interactive.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the player is on the main menu screen, when the player uses keyboard navigation (e.g., Tab key) to focus on the 'New Game' button and presses the activation key (e.g., Enter or Spacebar), then the application transitions to the Game Setup screen.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given the player is on the main menu screen, when the player clicks the 'New Game' button multiple times in quick succession, then the application transitions to the Game Setup screen only once, without errors or unexpected behavior.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Code reviewed and approved by team, Integration testing confirms the transition between Main Menu and Game Setup scenes is successful, Accessibility requirements for keyboard navigation are validated

title: Configure a game with one to three AI opponents
user_role: Any player initiating a new game session.
description: As a player setting up a new game, I want to select the number of AI opponents from a choice of one, two, or three, so that I can customize the game's challenge, duration, and overall experience to my preference.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given I am on the game setup screen, when I select '1' as the number of AI opponents and start the game, then a new game session is created with a total of two players: one human and one AI.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given I am on the game setup screen, when I select '3' as the number of AI opponents and start the game, then a new game session is created with a total of four players: one human and three AIs.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given I am on the game setup screen, when I change the selected number of AI opponents from '1' to '3', then the UI dynamically updates to display configuration sections for three distinct AI opponents.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Code reviewed and approved by at least one other developer, Integration testing confirms that the selection correctly influences the number of players at game start, Story is deployed and verified in the staging environment

title: Set a unique difficulty level for each AI opponent
user_role: The Human Player configuring a new single-player game session.
description: As a Human Player setting up a new game, I want to independently assign a difficulty level (Easy, Medium, or Hard) to each of my AI opponents so that I can customize the game's challenge to match my skill level and desired experience, enhancing replayability.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given I am on the Game Setup screen and have selected 3 AI opponents, when I set the difficulty for 'AI 1' to 'Easy', 'AI 2' to 'Hard', and 'AI 3' to 'Medium', then the UI must clearly display 'Easy' for AI 1, 'Hard' for AI 2, and 'Medium' for AI 3 respectively.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given I am on the Game Setup screen, when I increase the number of AI opponents from 1 to 2, then a new UI section for 'AI 2' appears, and its difficulty selector defaults to 'Medium'.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given I have configured a game with two AI opponents set to 'Easy' and 'Hard', when I start the game, then the game loads and the internal PlayerState objects for the two AIs must be initialized with 'ai_difficulty' properties of 'Easy' and 'Hard' respectively.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Integration testing confirms that selected difficulties are correctly passed to the game state on start, User interface on the Game Setup screen is implemented as specified and approved, Story deployed and verified in the staging environment

title: Create a player profile with a custom name
user_role: Any human player starting a new game session.
description: As a new or returning player, I want to create a personal profile by entering a custom name, so that my game progress, historical statistics, and high scores are saved and displayed under my unique identity, enhancing my sense of ownership and achievement.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given the player is on the game setup screen which contains a profile name input field, when the player enters a valid name (e.g., 'BoardwalkKing') and proceeds with game setup, then a new player profile is created and persisted with the entered name and a unique internal profile_id, and the game setup continues to the next step.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the player is on the game setup screen, when the player enters a name with fewer than 3 characters (e.g., 'Ty') and attempts to proceed, then a user-friendly validation message is displayed indicating the name is too short, and the game setup does not proceed.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given a player has successfully created a profile with the name 'CashMoney', when the game starts, then the human player's name is displayed as 'CashMoney' in the main game HUD.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Code reviewed and approved by team, Integration testing for database persistence completed successfully, User interface reviewed and approved for usability and adherence to requirements

title: Receive feedback for an invalid profile name
user_role: Any player creating or editing their profile on the Game Setup screen.
description: As a player setting up my profile, I want to receive immediate and clear feedback if the name I enter is invalid, so that I can easily correct it and proceed to start the game without frustration.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given the player is on the game setup screen in the profile name input field, when the player enters a name with fewer than 3 characters (e.g., 'Al'), then a specific error message 'Name must be at least 3 characters long' is displayed below the input field, and the option to proceed is disabled.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the player is on the game setup screen in the profile name input field, when the player enters a name containing special characters (e.g., 'Player!@#', 'Mr. Monopoly'), then a specific error message 'Name can only contain letters and numbers' is displayed, and the option to proceed is disabled.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given the player has entered an invalid name and an error message is currently displayed, when the player edits the name so that it meets all validation criteria, then the error message disappears, and the option to proceed becomes enabled.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Code reviewed and approved by at least one other developer, Unit tests for the validation logic implemented with >= 90% coverage and passing, User interface reviewed and approved for clarity and responsiveness

title: View my persistent historical gameplay statistics
user_role: The human player who has created a profile and wants to see their long-term performance.
description: As a returning player, I want to access a dedicated screen that displays my cumulative gameplay statistics from all my completed games, so that I can track my performance, see my win/loss record, and feel a sense of long-term progression and achievement.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given the player has completed at least one game and has historical statistics saved, when the player selects the 'Player Statistics' option from the main menu, then a dedicated statistics screen is displayed, and the screen correctly shows values for: Total games played, Total wins, Win/Loss ratio, and other required stats.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the player has created a profile but has not completed any games, when the player navigates to the 'Player Statistics' screen, then the screen displays all statistical categories with appropriate default values (e.g., 'Total Games Played: 0', 'Win/Loss Ratio: N/A').
acceptance_criteria_3: Given the player has existing statistics, including 'Total Games Played' = 5 and 'Total Wins' = 2, when the player completes and wins a new game and returns to the main menu, then the 'Total Games Played' statistic displays '6' and the 'Total Wins' displays '3'.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests for the data access layer and statistics calculation logic are implemented with >= 70% coverage and passing, Integration testing for the game-completion-to-database-update flow is completed successfully, Performance requirements for screen load time are verified

title: Select my player token from a set of classic options
user_role: Human Player (during game setup)
description: As a player setting up a new game, I want to choose my game piece from a visual selection of classic tokens, so that I can personalize my in-game identity and feel more connected to the game experience.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given the player is on the game setup screen, when the player clicks on an available token (e.g., 'Top Hat') from the selection interface, then the 'Top Hat' token becomes visually highlighted, and any previously selected token is deselected. A preview of the 'Top Hat' is shown next to the player's name.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the player has selected a token and configured a game with 3 AI opponents, when the player starts the game, then the AI opponents are each assigned a unique token from the pool of tokens not selected by the human player. No two players in the game have the same token.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given the player selected the 'Battleship' token during game setup and started the game, when the main game view loads, then the player's 3D game piece on the board is the 'Battleship', and the player's icon in the HUD is the 'Battleship'.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Integration testing completed to ensure the selected token ID is correctly passed to the game state, User interface reviewed and approved for visual polish and usability, Story deployed and verified in staging environment

title: Roll two six-sided dice to start my move
user_role: The human player actively taking their turn.
description: As a human player whose turn it is, I want to click a button to roll two virtual dice, so that I can determine the number of spaces my token will move and proceed with my turn.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given it is the human player's turn, their status is 'Active', and they are in the 'Pre-Roll Management Phase', when the player clicks the 'Roll Dice' button, then the system generates two random integer values, each between 1 and 6 inclusive, using a cryptographically secure method.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given it is an AI player's turn OR the human player is not in the 'Pre-Roll Management Phase', when the game state is updated, then the 'Roll Dice' button is visually disabled and non-interactive.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given the player has set the 'Game Speed' setting to 'Fast' or 'Instant', when the player clicks the 'Roll Dice' button, then the dice roll animation duration is significantly shortened for 'Fast' or skipped entirely for 'Instant'.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests for dice generation and doubles logic implemented with >= 70% coverage and passing, 3D dice animation is implemented and visually polished, Performance requirements verified on target hardware

title: Watch my token automatically move around the board
user_role: The human player interacting with the game board.
description: As a player, I want to see my game token animate its movement from one space to the next after I roll the dice, so that I can visually track my progress around the board and have an immersive, intuitive gameplay experience.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given the player's token is on 'St. Charles Place' (index 11) and the game speed is 'Normal', when the player completes a dice roll with a total of 5, then the token animates moving sequentially across 5 spaces, landing on 'Indiana Avenue' (index 16). The camera smoothly follows the token's movement.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the player has set the 'Game Speed' to 'Instant' in the settings menu, when the player's token needs to move, then the token instantly teleports to the destination space without a sequential movement animation. A brief visual effect (e.g., a flash or particle burst) occurs at the destination to signify the move.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given a player's turn results in them being sent to Jail (e.g., landing on 'Go to Jail' space), when the game logic directs the player to Jail, then the token does not animate space-by-space. Instead, a special, direct animation plays, moving the token from its current space directly to the 'In Jail' section of the board.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Code reviewed and approved by team, User interface animation and camera movement reviewed and approved for smoothness and visual appeal, Performance requirements verified on target hardware

title: Receive an extra turn after rolling doubles
user_role: Any active player in the game (human or AI).
description: As a player (human or AI), I want to be granted an immediate, additional turn after I roll doubles, so that the game correctly follows the official Monopoly rules and provides an authentic gameplay experience.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given it is a player's turn, they are not in jail, and their consecutive doubles count is 0, when the player rolls the dice and the result is doubles (e.g., two 4s), then the player's token moves the total number of spaces, the action for the destination space is completed, the game state confirms it is still the same player's turn, and their consecutive doubles count is incremented to 1.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given a player has just completed a turn by rolling doubles and their consecutive doubles count is 1, when the player rolls the dice again on their extra turn and the result is not a double, then the player moves and completes the action, their consecutive doubles count is reset to 0, and the turn passes to the next player in sequence.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given a player is in the 'InJail' state and chooses to roll the dice, when the player rolls doubles, then the player's state changes from 'InJail' to 'Active', they move the number of spaces indicated by the dice, complete their action, and their turn ends. They are NOT granted an extra turn.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests implemented for the turn logic and doubles counter, achieving required coverage, Integration testing completed for the full turn sequence, including the 'get out of jail' exception, Story deployed and verified in staging environment

title: Be sent to jail for rolling three consecutive doubles
user_role: Human Player, AI Player
description: As a player, I want the game to automatically send my token to jail if I roll three consecutive doubles in a single turn, so that the game correctly enforces the official rules and maintains the strategic balance of risk and reward associated with rolling doubles.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given a player is taking their turn and has already rolled doubles twice in a row, when the player rolls the dice for a third time and the result is doubles, then the player's token is immediately moved directly to the 'In Jail' space, the player's turn ends, and play passes to the next player.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given a player has rolled doubles twice and is on a space near GO (e.g., Boardwalk), when the player rolls their third consecutive double, then the player's token does not move the number of spaces indicated by the dice, is sent directly to Jail, and does not collect the $200 GO salary.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given a player has rolled doubles once or twice consecutively, when the player's next roll in the same turn is not doubles, then the player moves normally, their turn ends, and their consecutive doubles counter is reset to zero.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests covering all logic branches for the doubles counter and jail condition are implemented and passing with >70% coverage for the modified modules, Integration testing completed successfully, verifying the interaction between the dice roller, turn manager, and player state

title: Collect $200 salary when passing or landing on GO
user_role: Player (Human and AI)
description: As a Player, I want my cash balance to be automatically credited with a $200 salary so that the game correctly follows the official rules and I receive the funds I am entitled to for completing a lap of the board.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given a player's token is on 'Boardwalk' (space 39) with a cash balance of $500, when the player rolls a 5, causing their token to move past GO and land on 'Baltic Avenue' (space 3), then the player's cash balance is automatically increased to $700 ($500 + $200).
acceptance_criteria_2: Given a player's token is on 'Pennsylvania Avenue' (space 28) with a cash balance of $500, when the player rolls a 2 and lands on the 'Go to Jail' space (space 30), then the player's token is moved directly to the 'In Jail' location (space 10) and their cash balance remains $500.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given a player's move qualifies them to collect a $200 salary, when the salary is credited to their account, then a non-intrusive visual indicator (e.g., '+ $200' text animation) appears near their HUD element, and a positive confirmation sound effect is played.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests covering all scenarios (pass, land, no pass, go to jail) implemented and passing with >95% coverage for the salary calculation module, Integration testing completed to verify PlayerState is correctly updated within the game loop, User interface feedback (visual and audio) reviewed and approved

title: Get out of jail by paying the $50 fine
user_role: The human player whose turn has started and whose status is 'InJail'.
description: As a player who is in jail, I want to be presented with the option to pay a $50 fine at the beginning of my turn, so that I can immediately get out of jail and continue my turn normally, allowing me to maintain momentum in the game.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given I am in the 'InJail' state, it is the start of my turn, and my cash balance is $1500, when the game presents the 'Get Out of Jail' options and I select the 'Pay $50 Fine' option, then my cash balance is reduced to $1450, my player status is updated from 'InJail' to 'Active', my 'jail_turns_remaining' counter is reset, and I proceed to the Pre-Roll Management phase of my turn.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given I am in the 'InJail' state, it is the start of my turn, and my cash balance is $49, when the game presents the 'Get Out of Jail' options, then the 'Pay $50 Fine' option is visually disabled and non-interactive.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given I am in the 'InJail' state, it is the start of my turn, and my cash balance is exactly $50, when I select the 'Pay $50 Fine' option, then my cash balance is reduced to $0, my player status is updated to 'Active', and I proceed with my turn.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests implemented for the payment logic with >90% coverage, including all edge cases, Integration testing completed successfully for the UI-to-GameState flow, User interface reviewed and approved for clarity and usability

title: Get out of jail by using a 'Get Out of Jail Free' card
user_role: The human player who is currently in the 'InJail' state and possesses at least one 'Get Out of Jail Free' card.
description: As a player who is in jail and owns a 'Get Out of Jail Free' card, I want to be presented with the option to use it at the start of my turn, so that I can get out of jail immediately without spending money or relying on a lucky dice roll.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given the player's status is 'InJail', it is the start of their turn, and their 'get_out_of_jail_cards' count is 1, when the player is presented with their jail options and selects 'Use Get Out of Jail Free Card', then the player's 'status' is updated to 'Active', their 'get_out_of_jail_cards' count becomes 0, and they proceed to the Pre-Roll Management Phase of a normal turn.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the player uses a 'Get Out of Jail Free' card that originated from the Chance deck, when the action to use the card is confirmed, then the specific 'Get Out of Jail Free' card is placed at the bottom of the Chance card deck.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given the player's status is 'InJail' and their 'get_out_of_jail_cards' count is 0, when their turn begins and the jail options are presented, then the UI option to 'Use Get Out of Jail Free Card' is not displayed or is disabled.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests covering the state changes in PlayerState and DeckState are implemented and achieve >70% coverage for new code, Integration testing for the full action (UI click -> state update -> turn progression) completed successfully, The feature is verified as functional in a staging build

title: Attempt to get out of jail by rolling for doubles
user_role: The human player whose turn it is and whose status is 'InJail'.
description: As a player in jail, I want to choose the option to roll the dice on my turn, so that I can attempt to get out of jail for free by rolling doubles, preserving my cash and 'Get Out of Jail Free' cards.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given I am in the Jail space with a status of 'InJail' and it is the start of my turn, when I select the 'Roll for Doubles' option and the roll is doubles, then my player status is updated from 'InJail' to 'Active', I move the total number of spaces on the dice, and my turn ends without an extra roll.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given I am in the Jail space with a status of 'InJail', it is the start of my turn, and I have 3 or 2 'jail_turns_remaining', when I select the 'Roll for Doubles' option and the roll is NOT doubles, then my 'jail_turns_remaining' is decremented by 1 and my turn immediately ends.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given it is the start of my turn and my status is 'InJail', when the pre-roll management phase begins, then a modal UI dialog is presented with my available options, and the dialog must contain a clearly labeled 'Roll for Doubles' button.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests covering state transitions and rule logic are implemented with >80% coverage, Integration testing for the full jail-to-active flow is completed successfully, The special rule for 'no extra turn on doubles' is explicitly tested and verified

title: Be forced to pay the fine after failing to roll doubles for 3 turns in jail
user_role: The Human Player
description: As a player in jail for my third consecutive turn, I want the game to automatically force me to pay the $50 fine if I fail to roll doubles, so that the official game rules are enforced and my turn can proceed correctly.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given a player is in the 'InJail' state, their 'jail_turns_remaining' count is 1 (indicating the 3rd turn), and they have more than $50 cash, when the player chooses to roll the dice and the result is not doubles, then the player's cash balance is reduced by $50, their status changes to 'Active', their token moves the number of spaces shown on the dice, and their turn ends.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given a player is in the 'InJail' state and their 'jail_turns_remaining' count is 1, when the player chooses to roll the dice and the result is doubles, then the player's cash balance is not changed, their status changes to 'Active', their token moves, and their turn ends without an extra roll.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given a player is in the 'InJail' state, their 'jail_turns_remaining' count is 1, and they have less than $50 cash, when the player rolls the dice and the result is not doubles, then the game flow is paused, and the player is prompted to raise funds to cover the $50 debt. If they fail, the bankruptcy process is initiated.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests covering all scenarios (sufficient funds, insufficient funds, doubles roll, non-doubles roll) are implemented and passing with >70% coverage, Integration testing with the bankruptcy and asset management systems completed successfully

acceptance_criteria_3: Given a player is on any Chance space, when the player draws the 'Go to Jail' card, then the card is displayed, the player's token moves directly to the 'In Jail' section, their status is set to 'InJail', they do not collect $200, and their turn immediately ends.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests implemented for card effect logic and deck management, achieving >70% coverage for the new code, All 16 standard Chance cards are implemented and tested, The card data is successfully loaded from an external JSON file

title: Choose to buy an unowned property I land on
user_role: Human Player

title: Choose to send an unowned property to auction instead of buying it
user_role: The Human Player

acceptance_criteria_2: Given the purchase decision dialog for an unowned property is displayed, when I click the 'Auction' button, then the purchase decision dialog closes immediately and the auction process begins, involving all active players (human and AI).
acceptance_criteria_3: Given I am the human player and have landed on an unowned property that I do not have sufficient cash to purchase, when the game presents me with the purchase decision dialog, then the 'Buy' button must be visually disabled and non-interactive, while the 'Auction' button remains enabled.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests for button state logic implemented and passing with >80% coverage, Integration testing with the Auction Manager (US-032) completed successfully, Functionality verified on all target aspect ratios

title: Participate in an auction for a property
user_role: Human Player
description: As a Human Player, I want to participate in a turn-based auction for an unowned property, placing bids against AI opponents, so that I have a strategic opportunity to acquire properties that were not purchased outright and can compete to complete my sets or block my opponents.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given an auction is in progress for 'Boardwalk' and it is the human player's turn to bid, when the human player places a valid winning bid and all other players withdraw, then the auction UI closes, the final bid amount is deducted from the human player's cash, and the 'Boardwalk' property is added to their portfolio.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given an auction is in progress and it is the human player's turn to bid, when the human player selects the 'Withdraw' or 'Pass' option, then the human player is marked as inactive for this auction, their bidding controls are disabled, and the turn passes to the next player in the bidding order.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given an auction is started by Player 2 in a 4-player game (Human, AI-1, AI-2, AI-3), when the auction begins, then the first player to bid is Player 2, followed by AI-2, then AI-3, then the Human, and so on, skipping any players who have withdrawn.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing., Unit tests covering auction logic (bidding, winning, withdrawing) achieve >80% coverage., Integration tests for the full auction lifecycle (trigger -> bidding -> resolution -> game resume) are implemented and passing., The auction UI has been reviewed for clarity and usability.

title: Build houses on properties in a complete color set
user_role: Human Player
description: As a player who owns a complete color set, I want to purchase and build houses on those properties so that I can increase the rent value and gain a strategic advantage over my opponents.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given I am the active player, it is my turn, I own all properties in the Light Blue color set, have at least $50 cash, and the bank has houses available, when I choose to build one house on Oriental Avenue, then my cash is reduced by $50, the bank's available house count decreases by one, and a house appears on the Oriental Avenue space on the board.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given I own Oriental Avenue and Vermont Avenue, but not Connecticut Avenue, when I access the property management screen, then the option to build houses on Oriental Avenue or Vermont Avenue is disabled or hidden, and a tooltip indicates that a complete color set is required to build.

acceptance_criteria_1: Given I own a three-property monopoly where Property A has 1 house, and Properties B and C have 0 houses, when I attempt to build a second house on Property A, then the action is blocked, and the UI provides feedback explaining that I must build evenly.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given I own a monopoly where every property has exactly one house, when I attempt to build a second house on any single property in that set, then the transaction is successful, and the selected property now has two houses.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given I own a monopoly where Property A has 3 houses, and Properties B and C each have 2 houses, when I attempt to sell a house from Property B or C, then the action is blocked, and the UI indicates that I must sell from the property with the most houses first (Property A).
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests for the `CanBuildOnProperty` and `CanSellFromProperty` validation logic implemented with >80% coverage, Integration testing completed successfully, verifying UI feedback and state changes, User interface reviewed and approved for clarity of feedback

title: Upgrade a set of 4 houses to a single hotel
user_role: The human player who has achieved a full monopoly and is looking to maximize their property's rent potential.

acceptance_criteria_2: Given I own a monopoly with 4 houses on each property and have sufficient cash, when I attempt to purchase a hotel, but the Bank's supply of 12 hotels is exhausted, then the transaction is blocked, and a UI notification clearly informs me of the hotel shortage.

title: Notify player of building shortage when attempting to build

title: Respond to a trade offer from an AI opponent

title: See a victory screen when I am the last player remaining

title: View a detailed game summary screen after a match ends

title: View at-a-glance information for all players in the HUD
user_role: The human player of Monopoly Tycoon, who needs real-time game state information for strategic planning.
description: As a player, I want a persistent on-screen display showing the name, token, and current cash for every player, so that I can instantly assess the financial standing of my opponents and myself to make better strategic decisions throughout the game.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given a new 4-player game has started, when the main game board scene is loaded, then a persistent HUD is visible with four panels, each correctly displaying the player's name, token icon, and starting cash of $1500.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given a game is in progress and it is Player 1's turn, when the player views the game screen, then Player 1's panel in the HUD has a distinct visual highlight (e.g., a glowing border) that is not present on other players' panels.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given a player has a cash balance of $1000 displayed in the HUD, when the player passes GO and collects a $200 salary, then the player's cash display in the HUD immediately updates to show $1200.

title: See clear visual indicators of property ownership on the board
user_role: The human player interacting with the game board.
description: As a player, I want clear, player-specific visual indicators on each property space on the board so that I can instantly understand who owns what, identify monopolies, and make faster strategic decisions.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given a property on the board is unowned, when a player successfully purchases that property, then a visual indicator corresponding to the purchasing player's unique color/token immediately appears on the property space.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given a player owns a property and its standard ownership indicator is displayed, when the player mortgages that property, then the ownership indicator's visual state changes to clearly signify it is mortgaged (e.g., becomes greyed-out), while still being identifiable as belonging to the owner.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given Player A owns Property X and Player B owns Property Y, when Player A and Player B complete a trade, exchanging ownership, then the marker on Property X immediately updates to show Player B's ownership, and the marker on Property Y updates to show Player A's ownership.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Integration testing completed for all trigger events (purchase, trade, mortgage, bankruptcy), Performance requirements verified under a fully populated board scenario, Accessibility requirement for non-color-based indicators is met

title: Interact with modal dialogs for critical decisions
user_role: The human player of Monopoly Tycoon.
description: As a human player, I want the game to pause and display a focused, interactive pop-up for critical, turn-halting decisions, so that I can consciously evaluate my options and make informed choices without the risk of missing important game events.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given I am the human player, when I land on an unowned property, then the game's background processes are paused, and a modal dialog is displayed showing the property's title deed and presenting 'Buy' and 'Auction' buttons.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given I am the human player and an AI opponent has proposed a trade, when the trade offer is presented, then the game's background processes are paused, a modal dialog is displayed showing the trade details, and presenting 'Accept', 'Decline', and 'Propose Counter-Offer' buttons.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given any critical decision modal dialog is active on screen, when I attempt to click on any UI element outside of the modal dialog, then the clicks are ignored, and only interactions with the elements inside the modal dialog are registered.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing., A reusable modal dialog prefab and controlling script have been created., The modal system is successfully integrated for the property purchase, trade response, and income tax scenarios., Integration tests confirm that game events correctly trigger the UI and UI events correctly trigger game logic.

title: Access a dedicated interface to manage all my properties
user_role: The Human Player who needs to make strategic decisions about their asset portfolio.

acceptance_criteria_1: Given it is the human player's turn, before they have rolled the dice, when the player clicks the 'Manage Properties' button in the main HUD, then a dedicated property management screen is displayed, overlaying the main game board.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the player has a complete, undeveloped monopoly and sufficient cash to build a house, when the player selects a property from that monopoly and clicks the 'Build House' button, then the player's cash is debited by the correct building cost and the player's total cash, displayed on the screen, is updated immediately.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given the player owns a monopoly where one property has 1 house and the others have 0, when the player selects the property that already has 1 house, then the 'Build House' button for that property is disabled and an informative tooltip explains that building must be even across the set.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing., Unit test coverage for UI logic and state validation meets the 70% project standard., Integration tests for all property management actions are implemented and passing., UI has been reviewed and approved by a UX/UI designer or product owner.

title: Use a two-panel interface to build and review trade offers
user_role: The human player of Monopoly Tycoon, who may have varying levels of experience with the game.
description: As a Human Player, I want a clear, two-panel trading interface that displays my items and the opponent's items side-by-side so that I can easily construct, review, and understand trade offers to make strategic decisions effectively.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given it is the human player's turn, when the player selects an AI opponent and chooses the 'Trade' option, then a modal trading interface appears, displaying two main panels: 'Your Offer' and 'Their Offer', with available assets displayed for selection.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the trading interface is open, and the player owns a property with at least one house, when the player attempts to select the developed property to add to their offer, then the property is visually disabled in the selection list, and a tooltip states 'Cannot trade properties with buildings'.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given an AI opponent initiates a trade with the human player, when the trade offer is presented to the player, then the same two-panel interface appears, pre-populated with the AI's offer, and buttons for 'Accept', 'Decline', and 'Propose Counter-Offer' are displayed.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing., Unit tests for trade validation logic achieve >80% coverage., Integration tests confirm that game state is correctly updated after a trade., The trading UI has been manually tested for all scenarios, including error conditions and edge cases.

title: Access an in-game settings menu
user_role: The human player of Monopoly Tycoon.
description: As a player in the middle of a game, I want to access a settings menu without quitting the match, so that I can adjust game options, save my progress, or exit the game in a controlled manner.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given a game is in progress and it is the human player's turn, when the player presses the 'Escape' key, then the game simulation is paused and a settings menu overlay is displayed.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the in-game settings menu is open, when the player views the menu, then the menu must contain distinct, clickable options for 'Resume Game', 'Settings', 'Save Game', 'Load Game', 'Return to Main Menu', and 'Quit to Desktop'.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given a modal dialog (e.g., a trade offer) is displayed to the player, when the player attempts to open the settings menu, then the settings menu does not open, and the modal dialog remains the focus of interaction.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests for the pause/resume logic are implemented with >80% coverage and are passing, Integration testing for opening/closing the menu in various game states is completed successfully, Performance requirements for menu responsiveness are verified

title: Adjust the game speed to make animations faster or instant
user_role: The Experienced or Impatient Player who understands the game mechanics and wishes to complete matches more efficiently.
description: As an experienced player, I want to change the game speed setting so that I can reduce waiting times for animations and AI decisions, allowing for a faster-paced game.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given the player is in a game, when the player navigates to the settings menu and selects the 'Fast' or 'Instant' game speed option, then all subsequent game animations (e.g., dice rolls, token movement) play at an accelerated rate or are skipped, and artificial AI decision delays are reduced or eliminated.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the game speed is set to 'Fast' or 'Instant' and the human player is involved in a property auction, when the auction begins, then the game speed is automatically and temporarily set to 'Normal' for the entire duration of the auction.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given a player has set the game speed to 'Fast', when the player saves the game, exits, and then loads that saved game, then the game speed setting is correctly restored to 'Fast' and the game continues at that pace.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests for the speed controller and auction override logic are implemented with sufficient coverage and are passing, Integration testing for UI interaction and save/load persistence is completed successfully, Manual E2E testing confirms a smooth and consistent experience on all speed settings

title: Adjust master
user_role: music
description: and sound effect volumes independently

story_points: As a player, I want to independently adjust the master, music, and sound effect volume levels so that I can customize the game's audio to my personal preference for a more enjoyable experience.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given the player is in the settings menu and background music is playing, when the player moves the 'Music' volume slider, then the volume of the background music changes in real-time to match the slider's value, and the new setting is immediately persisted.
technical_tasks: Given the player is in the settings menu, when the player moves the 'Sound Effects' volume slider, then a sample sound effect (e.g., a button click or dice sound) is played at the new volume level, and the new setting is immediately persisted.
definition_of_done: Given the player has set the Music volume to 30% and Sound Effects volume to 80%, when the player closes the game completely and then relaunches it, then the game's audio levels for music and sound effects are at 30% and 80% respectively, and the sliders in the settings menu reflect these saved values.

title: Reset all my historical statistics and high scores
user_role: The Data-Conscious Player who wants control over their persistent game data, allowing for a fresh start.

acceptance_criteria_1: Given I have existing historical statistics, when I navigate to the settings menu, click the 'Reset All Player Data' button, and click 'Confirm' on the subsequent confirmation dialog, then all my historical player statistics are reset to their default zero state, and my high scores are cleared.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given I have existing historical statistics, when I click the 'Reset All Player Data' button and then click 'Cancel' on the confirmation dialog, then no data is modified or deleted.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given I am in the settings menu, when I click the 'Reset All Player Data' button, then a modal confirmation dialog appears, which warns me that the action is permanent and cannot be undone.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests implemented for the data reset service, achieving required coverage, Integration testing completed to verify database transaction integrity, Manual E2E testing confirms the feature works as expected across all scenarios

title: Provide a bulk deletion option for all saved games via the settings menu
user_role: The System-Conscious Player who wants control over their application data and the ability to perform a 'hard reset' on their progress.

acceptance_criteria_1: Given the user has at least one saved game file, when the user clicks the 'Delete All Saved Games' button in settings AND clicks 'Confirm' on the subsequent confirmation dialog, then all files within the '%APPDATA%/MonopolyTycoon/saves' directory are permanently deleted.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the user has at least one saved game file and has opened the deletion confirmation dialog, when the user clicks the 'Cancel' button, then the confirmation dialog closes AND no files are deleted.

title: Start an optional interactive tutorial to learn the game
user_role: New Player or First-Time User, who may be unfamiliar with the Monopoly rules or the game's specific user interface.
description: As a new player, I want to start an optional, interactive tutorial so that I can learn the basic rules and game controls in a guided, hands-on environment before playing a full game.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given the user is on the main menu screen, when the user clicks the 'Tutorial' button, then the game transitions to a dedicated, scripted tutorial game state.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the tutorial has started and it is the player's first turn, when the tutorial prompts the player to roll the dice by highlighting the 'Roll' button and displaying an instructional overlay, then the dice animate a pre-determined roll result, and the token moves accordingly.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given the player has completed the final guided action in the tutorial script, when the final action is confirmed, then a 'Tutorial Complete' modal dialog is displayed with options to 'Start New Game' or 'Return to Main Menu'.

title: Access and search a digital rulebook from game menus
user_role: Any player, from a novice learning the basics to an expert clarifying an edge-case rule.
description: As a player, I want to open a searchable digital rulebook from both the main menu and the in-game pause menu so that I can quickly find and clarify specific game rules without leaving the application.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given a player is in an active game, when the player opens the pause menu and clicks the 'Rulebook' button, then the rulebook UI is displayed as a modal overlay, and the game in the background is paused.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given the rulebook UI is open, when the player types a keyword (e.g., 'mortgage') into the search bar, then the list of rules is dynamically filtered to show only the sections and entries containing the keyword 'mortgage', and the keyword is visually highlighted in the results.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given the rulebook's source JSON file is missing or malformed, when the player attempts to open the rulebook, then a user-friendly error message is displayed (e.g., 'Rulebook data could not be loaded.'), the rulebook UI does not open, and an ERROR is written to the log file.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests for search logic and JSON parsing implemented with >80% coverage and passing, Performance requirements for search speed and UI loading verified, Error handling for missing/corrupt data file is confirmed to work as expected

title: Save game progress into one of several save slots
user_role: Any player of Monopoly Tycoon who may not have time to complete a full game in a single session.
description: As a player, I want to save my current game progress into a specific save slot at the start of my turn, so that I can safely exit the game and resume playing from the same point at a later time.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given I am in an active game and it is the start of my turn, before I have rolled the dice, when I open the pause menu, select 'Save Game', and click on an 'Empty' save slot, then the complete current GameState object is serialized into a versioned JSON file with a checksum in the '%APPDATA%/MonopolyTycoon/saves' directory.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given I am in the 'Save Game' menu and I click on a slot that contains a previously saved game, when a confirmation dialog appears and I select 'Yes', then the existing save file for that slot is replaced with the new game state data.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given it is an AI player's turn OR it is my turn but after I have rolled the dice, when I open the pause menu, then the 'Save Game' button is visually disabled and is not clickable.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing., Unit tests for serialization logic and state validation achieve >= 70% coverage., A successful end-to-end test of saving a game and then successfully reloading it (using functionality from US-062) has been completed., Performance of the save operation is confirmed to be under the 2-second threshold.

title: Load a game from a previously saved slot
user_role: A player who has previously started and saved at least one game session.
description: As a returning player, I want to select and load a previously saved game from the main menu, so that I can seamlessly continue my progress without having to start over.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given I am on the main menu and have at least one valid saved game file, when I navigate to the 'Load Game' screen, select the valid save slot, and confirm the load action, then the system deserializes the game state, transitions to the gameplay scene, and restores the entire game state to the moment it was saved.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given I am on the 'Load Game' screen, when the list of save slots is displayed, then each occupied and valid slot must display the player's profile name, the date and time of the save, and the turn number.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given I am on the 'Load Game' screen and at least one save file has failed its checksum validation, when the list of save slots is displayed, then the slot corresponding to the corrupted file is visually marked as 'Corrupted' or 'Unusable' and is disabled, preventing any attempt to load it.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests for deserialization, checksum validation, and version checking are implemented with >= 70% coverage and passing, Performance requirement for load time is verified, All error conditions (corruption, incompatibility, no files) are handled gracefully

title: Visually indicate unusable save files on the load game screen
user_role: Returning Player
description: As a Returning Player, I want to see a clear, visual indication on the load game screen for any save files that are corrupted or incompatible with the current game version, so that I can immediately understand which games I can no longer play and avoid the frustration of attempting to load a broken save file.
acceptance_criteria_1: Given a save file exists whose content does not match its stored checksum, when the player navigates to the 'Load Game' screen, then the entry for that save slot is visually distinct (e.g., greyed out) and clearly labeled as 'Corrupted'.
acceptance_criteria_2: Given a save slot is marked as 'Corrupted', when the player attempts to interact with it, then the 'Load' button for that slot is disabled, preventing any load attempt.
acceptance_criteria_3: Given a valid save file exists that was created with an older, incompatible version of the game, when the player navigates to the 'Load Game' screen, then the entry for that save slot is visually distinct and clearly labeled as 'Incompatible Version', and the load button is disabled.
definition_of_done: All acceptance criteria validated and passing, Unit tests for checksum validation, version comparison, and exception handling are implemented and passing with >80% coverage, Application remains stable when presented with malformed or invalid save files, Technical documentation for the save file format is updated

title: View a list of my top 10 victories
